Joke here:
A woman was married to a man that loved to go hunting a lot. She began complaining about him spending every Saturday morning hunting instead of being home. So one weekend he invites her to go with him. She agrees. They go to the woods and he gives her a rifle and a place to hunt from and told her to call for him if she needed any help. He proceeds on to his own hunting spot. Within minutes afater he settles into his own spot he hears a gunshot coming from his wife's direction. Then he hears another. He starts getting excited thinking "Maybe she got one!". He begins heading back to his wife when he hears another gun shot and can now make out some yelling. As he gets closer she is still shooting and he hears her yell out "Get away from my deer!", another gunshot and then another "Get Away From My Deer!". Now the man is really worried and as he reaches his wife he sees she is shooting at a man out in a field and she is just screaming "Get Away From My Deer!" and then that's when the the man she was shooting at yells back, "Lady you can keep the deer but can I just have my saddle back ?!"

Yrs ago during a Deer hunt,,something was approaching. I grabbed my rifle ,hunkered down behind a log and it approached. It was a Coyote ..As it stood there panting I'd admired the animal..I had no intention of harming it...Slowly it turned and as it did,,I saw the limp and blood dripping where it's leg had been shot off.. It was bleeding to death. I shot him. As I held it I wept. It was very large and beautiful. The teeth were so white they were blue. I know some justify killing them..I don't. I never took pleasure taking a buck either..The hunt I loved,,the tactics,the tracking..but seconds after the animal went down melancholy would set in..I loved the venison and taking the animal down yourself paid homage to the animal at every meal.  You would set down and remember the day. A few yrs ago I dropped one and as I approached I watched the life fade in it's eyes. From a rich crystal brown to a dull gray. It was my last hunt. I have nothing against hunting for food ,,but to hunt for bloodlust sickens me. This woman's entire story is a lie.

Once upon  time, nearly sixty years ago I was stalked in the concrete jungle by a deadly huntswoman.

She was such  a deadly shot she could take out the bottom of an empty Coca Cola tin, five out of five at 330 yards.

Alas, all the meat and fish she bagged were hunted at the local supermarket.

Over younger years she mercilessly slaughtered many an innocent cardboard target at ranges between fifty yards and half a mile.

She accompanied me on my non-trophy hunts including parts of Africa where the real bush meat hunting was cheap, because the local indigenous unfriendly hunters occupied the same wilderness space, and 9armed with AK47's, would hunt White men, not for their meat but for their trucks, cloths, sneakers, and, more recently their cell phones.

I remember a time, about forty years ago, when helped me and my little boys hanged about three quarters of a ton of bush meat for Jerry. It took nearly five hours to hang, and after drying made a quarter of a ton of Jerry, all legally hunted and for personal non commercial use.

Anyway, to cut a long story, I was her biggest catch, and, fifty eight years later, she still won't let go, and right now, as I type this, she still snores contentedly in my bed, next to me.

Our little boys, however, are far less of a success, having turned turned out Woke intolerant Democrats, and being White Conservatives are not politically worthy to meet our grandchildren.

When I was in high school I went Elk hunting in eastern Oregon with my Dad, Uncle, and cousin. The place where people camped contained several groups along about a 1/2 mile of road. A group at the end had a couple of mules to use as pack animals. Early one morning  as we were sitting around the fire eating breakfast we heard shots from the next camp down. We walked down the road and found the wife of one from that camp ‚ÄúTagging‚Äù one of the mules. She claimed it was a cow elk and none of us disputed her including the owner. He explained later that this was likely it‚Äôs  last hunt anyway. By the time the husband got there it was skinned out and in the game bag.
